description.text: a podium

A piggyback adaptor for converting your upright piano into a four-row Janko piano. This file includes one octave. For the standard piano you will need 7 of these.The purpose of the design is to offer the same fingering regardless of tonality (like a guitar) and provide freedom of thumb undertuck, thus cutting practice time by 12.

No drilling! This adaptor fits on top of the pivot line of the regular keys. And can be simply removed, but if you want total stability is could be fixed to the keys with double-sided tape. If you want you can paint the black keys black.

comments.text: Howdy! This is the future man, I'm so glad you made this. If I had to guess, piano converters will be huge because there are already SO MANY PIANOS. I'd love to modify the key tops and key support heights to make it into the wicki-hayden piggyback converter, though I'm only mediocre in openSCAD...
comments.author: JLMoriart

comments.text: Hi JL I have no idea how many people have actually printed this. I wish someone would leave a comment and say how it worked for them. In answer to your question, this design is made to fit the pivot length of upright pianos, which is shorter than grand piano pivot length. On the upright piano you just raise the top lid and then you can remove the front panel. The adaptor just sits on the pivots. If you were to use is on a grand the adaptor would get dragged forward each time you play a note. Weird.

description.text:
I designed this mount to fit snuggly on a picatinny rail for airsoft to mount a flashlight, laserpointer, round action cam, .....
All mounts I've seen so far, require a special diameter flashlight. With this mount it doesn't matter what size of flashlight you use. The flashlight or whatever you want to put in it, can be secured with rubber bands or a cord.
If you want extra security, you can download either the version with a nut and put in an M3 30mm screw and nut. Or you can use the one without a nut holder and use a nail or sth. like that.
If your mount fits to tight you might have to scale it up a couple percent.
I tried it and it fits pretty good and holds well only with friction.
If you have a question feel free to ask ;)

description.text: sss
Use this Calibration cube to teach your Palette about your 3D printer.

This is a model of the Pokemon Geodude, done in the low-polygon style. Low Poly objects are things designed with a low amount of polygons, giving them a blocky or 8-Bit feel. They can also be easier to 3D print, as objects with millions of polygons are harder to process.
I designed Geodude using Tinkercad. After the body was roughed in, I exported an STL and imported that file into Meshmixer where I decimated it (reduced the number of polygons) until it looked good. Then back into Tinkercad, where I removed it's left side, duplicated & flipped the right side and stuck it to the left, creating perfect bilateral symmetry.

Prints with supports. I found it best to rotate the model appx. 30 degrees backward, mainly so that the upper lip is perpendicular to the plate.

Geodude is available to copy-and-edit on Tinkercad.com:
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/cIu7vU9B91M-geodudelopoly
I appreciate Tinkercad

author: Seb200

description.text:
This is a BigAss CoreXY printer which allows up to 370x370x370 mm build volume! And can even made to allow bigger if you design it so, since I uploaded everything!

Enjoy!

Test Run (Speed is capped at 50.000 mm/min) :
https://youtu.be/UBUAHi7UNVE

Introduction

Why did I make another "DIY" printer design when there is so many? Well, because I thought it is a good project to learn 3D design, and about printers so I started it. Also, I wanted to keep things as simple as possible, with as little "complicated pieces" as you can.

All the pieces to build this machine can be sourced from AliExpress or Ebay sort of sites, so no need for "expensive" pieces.

The hard part for me was to find the smooth rods (since I didn't want to import them but had to anyway) and the build plate. Especially plate. Damn, it is so hard to find 420x420mm aluminum plate! :)

You can of course change it according to your needs an availability.

Please comment and suggest improvements if you have any, since it is not yet "a complete" project.

Almost every piece needed is in Fusion360 file but check out the BOM part below.

You need lots of M3 screws to lock the corners and pieces together but I've seen most of them are solid enough with just one screw to each side (despite most of them have 2 per side). Don't overtighten them, as it is ABS after all, not that hard to destroy!

<h2>BOM</h3>
  • 12x500mm 20x20 sigma rods (for frame)
  • 4xSc8UU bearings for bed holder (you can change design to use LM8UU instead)
  • 4x LM8UU bearings (for X carriage. You can work just fine with 2 either)
  • Lots of M3x10, M3x15, M3x30, M5x25 screws and nuts for attachment of pieces
  • GT2 belt, approx. 5m should do.
  • Idlers and pulleys (total number of 8 pieces). Design uses 3 mm bore ones for smooth ones (2 of them) and 5mm ones for 20t ones - but it is this way because I had ordered them this way :) You can change those holes on the connector corner pieces to fit your needs.
  • 2 extra pulleys for the motor shaft
  • An LJ18xxx series inductive sensor. If you want to use 4mm one, you have to modify the carriage a bit to make the sensor a tad closer to bed (approx. 3-4 mm more), and M12 hole instead of M18 one
  • E3D v6 (or clone) hotend kit. If you are going to use v5, you need to modify the x carriage a bit (make the coupler distances fit your needs)
  • One 12V radial fan for (part cooling if you want)
  • 6x8mm smooth rods (design is for 450mm long)
  • 2xT8 trapezoid rods (design is for 400 mm long)
  • 5xNEMA17 steppers
  • A MKS or Smoothieboard. Don't waste your time with Arduino based ones anymore - future is on ARM ! :P
  • A power supply (I use 12v generally)
  • PTFE tubing (for design is for Bowden type)
  • Cabling - I heard that Cat6 cables do really tidy up the space so I shall try them myself.
  • A heat pad - I bought 370x370 mm 220 V ones to use with a Solid State Relay, which I recommend for such a big printer. Don't even try to heat such a big plate with 12V bed solutions. Careful with the mains voltage!!!
  • Patience. Lots of it :)

<h2>Change Log</h3>

V2 Series V15

  • Reworked the bed carriage pieces, since the old one was unreliable.
  • Changed the X carriage so that it allows shorter range inductive probes
  • Changed the bed corners to a simpler one
  • Changed the top corners' idler holes to 3mm (it was 5mm before)
  • Other small tweaks

V72

  • Added a box for the controller board
  • Changed the two plate bed holding to sigma-rod based holder - plate I used was 3mm and was bending up and down, causing jams and shakes on the bed when bed is moving up or down.
  • Changed where the smooth rods are, because this way they were closer to the bed piece (still don't like the top holders though, but I just didn't bother myself a lot with it :) )
  • Fixed the holes in the "ext_carrier" piece - one of the holes on the surface was not exactly on the middle, so was a pain when installing :)
  • Made the "ext_carrier" a little thicker on the motor holding side to be safe

V50

  • Initial version

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/14C6MsHpV5T

The Twittee necklace 0.2 is a redesign of the Twittee necklace by David Sjunnesson. A lasercutted plexiglas jewelry.
ItÂ´s easy to make - give it a try!

Dear reader,
in the files attached you can find a short step by step introduction with pics of how to make the Twittee necklace 0.2 MY PROCESS:
I was looking up different pages with designideas like www.weupcycle.com unlimiteddesigncontest.org or www.thingiverse.com. They all invite the user to copy or redesign works of other designers. I found the design of a nice hanger on one of those pages (http://unlimiteddesigncontest.org/en/product/twittee-necklace) posted by David Sjunnesson. I downloaded the .svg file including the original vector graphics also called blueprint. I transformed the shapes in Illustrator and made two new variations of the hanger. Those two variation are attached as .svg so you can immediately start working with it. You can cut it out with a laserprinter or change the design first in Adobe Illustrator. How to change paths in Illustrator: http://www.khulsey.com/adobe-illustrator-paths-pen-tool.html I changed the round to more edgy shapes which i preffer.
After making two new variations i colored the outline red. All the red lines will be cutted later by the lasercutter. In case you want to engrave parts of the design (f.e. the wings...) you have to choose a second color for the lines and shapes you want to engrave. Save the Illustrator file as .svg CUTTING:
http://wiki.happylab.at/w/Laser_Cutter
I used site to find information about the fitting settings for different materials. ItÂ´s in german but it gives detailed information and has useful tricks.
My 4 mm thick blue plexiglas i cutted with power: 100 and speed: 0,5. Adding a string makes the hanger a necklace.

description.text:
I designed this mount to fit snuggly on a picatinny rail for airsoft to mount a flashlight, laserpointer, round action cam, .....
All mounts I've seen so far, require a special diameter flashlight. With this mount it doesn't matter what size of flashlight you use. The flashlight or whatever you want to put in it, can be secured with zip ties (the holes are 2 by 5 mm wide).
If you want extra security, you can download either the version with a nut and put in an M3 30mm screw and nut. Or you can use the one without a nut holder and use a nail or sth. like that.
If your mount fits to tight you might have to scale it up a couple percent.
I tried it and it fits pretty good and holds well only with friction.
If you have a question feel free to ask ;)

author: TheBlueSkywolf

title: The Mountster: a Raspberry Pi Camera Mount

description.text: The Mountster is a monster mount for the Raspberry Pi Camera. After looking at available designs online, I decided to make my own. A simple two piece design, fun, practical and fast to print. I used the Element 14 version to position the openings. The camera can be screwed in place using the two holes on the side of the lens and there is an opening for the focus light. This is a work in progress, so please send me issues and feedback!
Print and use the two screw holes on the side of the lens to secure the camera in place.

Here a ditrigonal dodecadodecahedron also called a triambic dodecadodecahedron.
Hart's image - http://www.georgehart.com/virtual-polyhedra/vrml/triambic_dodecadodecahedron.wrl - is not easily printed as it contains pentagons where portions of both sides face outwards. I recently constructed a version using only triangles and discovered that the stl file contained 13 pieces (shells). One piece was a great stellated dodecahedron and 12 pieces were simple 3D pentagrams. This means that one can construct a ditrigonal dodecadodecahedron by printing the 13 pieces separately and gluing them together. Stl files are: gr_stellated_dodecahedron.stl
four_3D_pentagrams.stl OpenSCAD code is included.

The 3D pentagrams are best print directly on the build platform; 12 are required.  The great stellated dodecahedron needs a raft and external support.  
I used a 30 second super glue with an activator pen. The great stellated dodecahedron was held firmly on a flat surface and glue applied to the five upper edges that touch the edges of a pentagram.  One of the pentagrams, with its points slightly dulled, was then held in place until the glue set.  The great stellated dodecahedron is turned as the 11 other pentagrams are added, one at a time.

Made in TinkerCAD as an experiment, I colored the flower with an orange, green, and brown sharpie, molded the petals using hot water, and grabbed a couple random stamen pieces from a discarded florist kit we had lying around and stuck them in to the rough inside section.

From later testing, a hair dryer will also work - in either case one must be careful not to burn themselves, and realize that it may take some time to get just right since the plastic cools down very quickly and can no longer be molded unless heated up again.

Tip: Wrap some electrical tape around the stem before you attach the clamp to it, this will prevent damage to your bicycle.

Suggestions are always welcome!

description.text: This activity helps students understand and calculate the rough cost to print their projects using the MakerBot Replicator printer and MakerBot filament. The calculations can be adjusted to meet your specific printer and filament. This project came about as a way for me to manage a valuable classroom resource and give students the opportunity to think like an engineer.
NGSS

This activity can be used in conjunction with any 3D printing project that your students may be doing. I utilize it in my classroom every time that students are interested in printing out a project. You can scaffold the math requirements to meet the needs of your students.
Having students explore the cost of materials ahead of printing helps to give them realistic expectations of what they are allowed to make in class. I typically limit students to $2.00 per pair of students for printing larger projects. Students need to then decide whether scaling their project up/down makes sense or if they need to reengineer the design of their model to meet the cost requirements.

Step 1 - Explore the material usage and cost of the pre-printed cubes. In advance it may be helpful to calculate the material usage and cost of the three cubes of different sizes for students to look at. Have students examine each of the cubes and provide observations about the weight and size of each one. Have students predict the cost to print each of the cubes. Step 3 will guide you through calculating the cost in advance. Step 2 - Determine the material usage for a student-designed project. After designing a project in your favorite tool of choice (mine is Tinkercad), students should import their STL file into Makerbot Print. Use the Print Preview button to get estimates for time and material. The material estimate will be in the form of grams. Step 3 - Calculate the cost of printing the project using data provided by the teacher. From here it is time to calculate a cost estimate of the project. To do this we can use the following formula. This formula assumes that you are using standard Makerbot filament that comes in the spools of 900g and costs $48 per roll. If you are using different filament, you may want to adjust the numbers listed. You can easily solve this on a calculator by multiplying the material use (in grams) by $48 and then dividing by 900 grams. The total will be in dollars.
The only materials needed for this project are some scratch paper and a calculator.
10 minutes

1) Make sure that your computers have MakerBot Print version 1.9 or above. This provides a material estimate that will be used to calculate the cost. 2) Optional Print out the three sets of cubes included in this project and calculate the weight and cost of each of them in advance.

comments.text: where do you get your filament? i pay $10 for 1kg ( 1000 g )
comments.author: TK3DPrinting

comments.text: Where are you getting filament for $10 a kg? I've experimented with a variety of filament, and currently use Hatchbox and a mix of some older Makerbot filament, but never for that low. Usually I pick it up on Amazon. I used the official retail pricing of the Makerbot filament since I figured that many people using Makerbot printers in classrooms will start out using Makerbot filament until they're comfortable looking for cheaper alternatives.

description.text:
This modification adds two stability rods for the Y axis, removing the tension from the frame in order to reduce noise. Also the position of the belt is now supposed to be exactly in the middle (not off by 1.5 mm). You should also be able to use the old belt holder.

Beware, the front plate isn't symmetrical. The front filler assumes the left side to be 10.7 cm, the right side to be 10.4 mm wide.

The motor holder I printed did not fit into the holes, even though it exactly matched the template. Strange enough, the holes did fit. Therefore I added a 30 mm version (distance between rectangular holes) and rasped my print until it fit.

I did use some other thingies as templates:

Printing:
I did print tho motor holder upright (Y-Motor_holder_full.obj): The cone for the right rod almost curled away. I added a file with additional support, "ac" == anti-curling.

I also added files for printing the motor holder on its back. These are untested.

Motor_holder_full_ac.obj has an additional support against that - hope that helps.

description.text:
Support for autolevel sensor.

My CTC Prusa i3 printer comes with a very strange extruder+hotend+aluminium support so it can difficult put some layer fan and more difficult use an autolevel sensor, so I had to design this piece that connected under the aluminium and around of the hot piece (but without touching it) allow fasten the autolevel sensor and adjust it using the both screws that there are under the extruder.

I advise to put washers to avoid touching the piece with the aluminium and other washers to avoid the screws deforms the groove.

This is my first piece, so I will be glad if it is useful to someone more.. :)

title: Lens holder for Logitech C270 HD (fixation lentille pour Logitech...)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Encore en l'état de Proof Of Concept,

J'en avais marre de la pince qui tiens la lentille... ça bouge, ça fait une zone noire dans la caméra, etc...
Alors j'ai dessiné vite fais cette pièce qui permet de visser une lentille grand angle (ou autre...FishEye...etc...) directement sur la webcam.

La pièce tient très bien car vissée dans la webcam avec les vis d'origines mais j'avoue qu'il y a un peu de jour autour...
Si quelqu'un à les dimensions de cette cam ça m'intéresse!
... sinon je me baserais sur des modèles déjà présent.

Comme vous l'aurais compris : Thing in progress!

lentille :
http://www.volumerate.com/product/oldshark-universal-3-in-1-clip-on-180-fish-eye-wide-angle-macro-lens-kit-for-iphone-more-844414768

EDIT 13/03/2017 : J'ai récupéré une base déjà existante et ajouté un anneau pour pouvoir régler le focus.
Avec un filament translucide, on peut voir le voyant comme quoi la caméra est allumée.

Still in the state of Proof Of Concept,

I was tired of the clamp holding the lens ... it moves, it makes a black area in the camera, etc ...
So I drew quickly this part which allows to screw a wide angle lens (or other ... FishEye ... etc ...) directly on the webcam.

The piece holds very well because screwed in the webcam with the original screws but I confess that there is a little space around ...
If someone knows the dimensions of this cam I'm interested!
... otherwise I would base myself on models already present.

As you would have understood: Thing in progress!

lens : http://www.volumerate.com/product/oldshark-universal-3-in-1-clip-on-180-fish-eye-wide-angle-macro-lens-kit-for-iphone-more-844414768

EDIT: I retrieved an already existing base and added a ring to be able to adjust the focus.
With a translucent filament, you can see the light that the camera is on.

author: Eebel

description.text:
You can use this design to attempt cranking the torque of any extruder that is connected with 4 M3 bolt and nuts in square configuration 31mm. You can reuse all parts you already have and insert this "gearbox" inbetween. You'll need some additional M3 bolts and nuts and an axel/nail of 5mm.

For me this improved greatly on skipped steps. Later I improved further with cranking Vref to 1V2 (0V6 in manual) - see the Benchy before and after.

The gear ratio is 1:3. As a result after installing you need to multiply your Esteps/mm x3 and reverse your extruder motor direction (e.g. Menu - Control - Motion + Store)
In order to lock the gears in place you'll need to flatten the nail on the positions of the screws through the gearshafts. I did that with a dremel/multigrinder.

Other things you need to consider when you find this an interesting thing:

  • increase the Vrefs for your stepper drivers (don't worry to go double the value, check temperature of drivers and motors to ensure yourself that you don't overload your equipment - just with your finger will do the trick)
  • don't block your nozzle or bowden tubes on the Geeetech Rostock 301: ALWAYS have 3 filaments loaded - push some filament through before and surely AFTER each print - incorporate it in your start/stop scripts if you can

29/Apr/2017: added new basic gear pair with less teeth. After 3 months my small gears wear slowly out so I decided to make something that at least looks more robust. Not yet tested per today. No hearingbone selfcentering thing this time, again in attempt to reduce detail on the gears and gain robustness.

May/2017: spray some WD40 on all moving/turning parts! No squeeking noises anymore, no melting plastics and no more skipped steps at all!

Dec/2017 - 1: added BasePlate2: a version with holes such that one can tighten the bolt on the big gear without having to take the whole thing apart (yep, I had it loose at some point)
Dec/2017 - 2: added Extruder_SimpleGear_Driver_NoScrollingOnAxis: a version with non circular axis hole. This requires to take of 1mm of material of your extruder axis such that the gear can be put on. I didn't figure out a way to do something similar for the big gear though.

Printer:

Geeetech Rostock 301

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20% & 55%

Notes:

Pay attention when slicing that you have good connecting from the center of the gears and alignment pins of the plates, with each contour of the skin. Options like in Cura 2.4 "Fill Gaps Between Walls" can help, as well as tuning down your line width such that your slicer clearly shows that the lines are equally distributed and connected to eachother.
Else... the teeth of the gear can break loose from the shaft walls... (sure you know how I know...)

If your axel/nail doesn't go through: don't attempt to drill it to size!
Either press on the gears firmly or gently revers drill with a smaller diameter drill or use mild abrasive.
The order of assembling is a bit nasty I still feel: put nuts in place in Base and Frontplate - screw on small gear - screw loosly Baseplate - screw big gear on new axel - put axel in Baseplate and align gears firmly - tighten screws on baseplate - put Frontplate in place - fix your Extruder Frame on Frontplate - and off you go.
Changing that order makes some screws unreachable... sorry... (see #3 remark further)

I wanted to enclose the gears such that nothing can get stuck between them by accident.
The screw positions could still be improved, but maybe that's for design iteration #3...
I used Autodesk Inventor Student Edition 2017 and have those files available - if they could serve you...
I choose for a Herringbone Gear (alike I guess) because I read that this is selfcentering - it can't take off to one or another side, they keep eachother in place. (like http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5111)

  • See also GearMakingExplanation.pdf and Parameters.xslx

I do have something similar when I think of it! But not every layer. In fact I assumed it was caused by the Cura slicer setting "Equalise flow" - or cqused by me fooling around in the printer control menu (I have put acceleration pretty low and jerk as well in an attempt NOT to overdrive the printer (e.g by trying to print at 120mm/s by accident - or by Equalise flow setting or ...) So now my printer just can't go too fast as it is not capable anymore. But yeah... it slows down 'sometimes' and then goes to normal speed again.
By the way: I also notice this when fiddling in the menu during a print - so it could also just be that the uP CPU gets choked by certain actions and causes the 'pause/hesitation'... Time might tell...

This is my first thing!
Ok, it's not very interesting, useful, or practical, but I needed practice stitching two stl files together for Dualstrusion. I thought I'd share the file, because maybe someone else might like it- or find it useful.I'm afraid that I currently only know how to use Rhino 3D... which most definitely is not open source. I've included the file, and I'll also include the vector trace that I made of the MakerBot logo for others to enjoy.
I'll upload a .svg file of the outline as soon as I have access to Adobe Illustrator.

I'm not sure I need to say much here- other than I found big problems with the plastic warping off my new Replicator... just a n00b I guess. I printed the file with a Raft on the base layer (A), just to be sure. I also heated the build plate by an extra 10 degrees, which seemed to do the trick. I've included my gcode and s3g files, for a quick build if you like. Note that they include the hotter build plate settings.

comments.text: I have found that 110 degrees for the build platform along with re-leveling the platform after every 3 or 4 builds does the trick.  I find the leveling critical and that it should be very tight to extrusion head.  The card should slip through but you should feel drag/friction.  As tight as you can get it without touching.  Minor adjustments make a big difference in avoiding warping issues.

I built this connector stabilizer for the USRP E310 Software Defined Radio. I wasn't satisfied with how much wobble the SMA-SMB adapters had, and I was afraid that I might accidentally snap off one of the connectors if I was using the radio in the field and accidentally whacked one of the antennas. This cover slips over the SMA-SMB adapters and gives a relatively snug fit, which reinforces the tiny little connectors from damage.

Unfortunately I neglected to include holes for the status LEDs... I will likely add this in the future. I am also designing a similar stabilizer for the USRP E312 radio, as I am in a research environment and deal with these radios frequently. title: 3DR Solo Controller HDMI Output Cable Brace v1

description.text:
Is your 3DR Solo's HDMI output cable not able to stay still while you fly? Is it ruining your ability to live stream? Well cry no more!

Print either, or, or both. This will stop your HDMIcable from flopping around, losing connection while you fly. If you are having issues with HDMI output with your 3DR Solo, it's probably this. I found that my live stream would drop if the cable moved even a single millimeter.

Installation:
Be very careful when using the "Plug Brace", as you must plug the cable straight into the HDMI plug of the controller. Since the "Plug Brace" is a friction fit between the phone mount, you can damage your plug by brute forcing the HDMI at an incorrect angle, resulting in a bad day. Also note that the two supports of the phone mount are slightly wider at the bottom, so slide it in from the bottom.

***Dimensions are based off of my own 3DR Solo controller and micro HDMI connector. If it doesn't fit, use an exacto blade or draft your own!

***Designed for m3 nuts and screws

comments.text: I ask you to join and add your part to the 3DR Solo Smart Drone Parts Group @ http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/3dr-solo-smart-drone-parts so as to make an easy place that all SOLO owners can go to find parts/mods. Best wishes.

remixed_from.title: M2 v4 dual extruder fan shroud

title: Makergear M2 Dual Extruder Fan Shroud

description.text:
This is an improved version of the fan shroud for the most recent version (Dec 2016) of the Makergear M2 with Dual Extruders.

All my prints used to have a huge quality difference between the side facing the fan and the side facing away from it. The original fan shroud design by jsc solved all these problems, but it would scrape along the small clamps that hold down the print plate and could in some cases lead to the motor skipping. I solved all these issues by decreasing the total height of the shroud and made some minor changes to the interior (mostly fillets).

It comes in two parts, but it is very easy to assemble with some hot glue.

Just like the previous version this prints without support. My suggestion is to rotate the model by 30 degrees along the x-axis and adding a skirt.

To mount it to the printer remove the covers on both fans and screw the assembled fan shroud to the top fan. To attach the part-cooling fan you can use either screws or tape, whatever you like best. I only used tape for quick prototyping.

title: Canopy Corners for Monoprice Dual head

description.text:
I have the Monoprice Dual Head Printer. I bought the Acrylic Canopy From FlashForge but the canopy would fall though the opening in the top of the printer. I designed the parts to hold the canopy in place. There are four parts Coner1 is placed in the corner underneath the frame Corner 2&3 screw on to the Corner1 and then Corner4 screws into that as a keeper so the Canopy can't slip off. Corner 2&3 adjust for the different length of the Canopy in the X and Y dimensions. You should be able to figure what corner they go in by holding them in place. I used two screws 12mm x 3mm with 6mm countersunk heads and a M3x8mm machine screw to hold the keeper on. The screws all self tap into the plastic.

Note Print 4 each of Corner1 & Corner2 and 2 each of Corner2 & Corner3. Make sure the Bernoulli tubes and the wire harness do not bind on the "T" cut out on the back side of the canopy. Mine was binding when the heads go to the front left corner when starting a print. I used my dremel tool to make an arc cut so the harness clears smoothly.

Since I made a cover for the front of the printer and hand hold covers ABS prints great. Before I used the canopy I was placing cardboard pieces over the top. I also use PEI on the heated bed and with these modifications ABS is my best printing material.

A simple tray that sits in the bottom of a backpack and stores lipo batteries when going out to the flying field. The tray is sized for 6 Turnigy Graphene 4s 1300mah packs.

These spool bushings are simple.  Use one or two elastic bands to install them on a spool.  Nothing else is required.  The center hole of the bushing is for a 1/4" smooth rod.  It can be easily increased with a drill bit.   
I have supplied spool bushing of 31, 39, 52 and 54 mm. They fit center holes of 32, 40, 53 and 55 mm respectively.  If you need another size, just give me the diameter of the center hole of your spool, and I will upload them.  The minimum size is 30 mm.

author: raeliean

description.text:
Forget handhelds! Give me a good old fashion SNES/Playstation controller. I loved the look of Kazy's retro TV but I wanted an all in one. This will require a large print bed as the parts are large. Mines 220mm x 220mm x 230mm. Some parts require gluing. The raspberry pi 3 mounts inside the TV. Shout out to Kazy for the original design. eBay is my go to for everything.

PARTS

Video

Note - HDMI is retropies primary video output. If you have an HDMI connection hooked up, it will auto to in once turned on. If not hooked up to an HDMI source, it will auto default to the secondary connection which is the a/v connection.

• 5" LCD screen - 19$ easy to crack open a cheap backup monitor and get the screen - http://www.ebay.com/itm/272521288290?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

• 4 pole audio/video connector - 1.20$ I made my own. Some solder and a couple of wires and you're in business - http://www.ebay.com/itm/252478906201?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Pinout can be found here - https://www.element14.com/community/thread/43364/l/raspberry-pi-2-av-output-via-rca-question?displayFullThread=true

• hdmi panel mount - 2.50$ - http://www.ebay.com/itm/391559192757?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

• 270o HDMI connector - 1$ - http://www.ebay.com/itm/331982437947?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Audio

Note - since this only has one speaker you will need to change the audio to mono output. You will only need to wire up the left chanel to the amp. This can be found here. http://pi.eggum.net/2013/09/airplay-or-shairport-that-is.html?m=1

• 36 mm speaker - 1$ - http://www.ebay.com/itm/142148466499?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

• 10k panel pot - 1$ - http://www.ebay.com/itm/301711852715?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

• 2.5 Watt PAM8302 Single Channel Amp - 1$ - http://www.ebay.com/itm/112205342859?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Wiring the Pot - https://forums.adafruit.com/viewtopic.php?f=8&t=108000

Power

Note - The way this is powered down is through emulation station. With a press of the button it fires back up. You could write a script to have the button both turn off and on the machine. its up to you.

• 3.7V Li-ion Battery Mini USB To USB A Power Supply Module - 2.99$ - http://www.ebay.com/itm/291644400220?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

• 5V to 12V DC-DC Converter - 1$ - This powers the monitor since it runs on 12 volts - http://www.ebay.com/itm/381853772475?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

• USB Cable Panel Mount Micro B Male to Micro B Female - 8$ - http://www.ebay.com/itm/172387577004?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

• Monoprice 8639 1.5ft USB 2.0 to Micro USB - 5$ - http://www.ebay.com/itm/231429806121?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

• 12mm Mini Round Waterproof ON/OFF Push button - 1$ - Doesn't have to be waterproof LOL. This hooks up to the reset pins on the Raspberry Pi (you have to solder them on). http://www.ebay.com/itm/192000073971?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&var=491616455207&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

Other Stuff

• 2 1ft USB 2.0 A Female Socket Panel Mount - 1.35$ x 2 - http://www.ebay.com/itm/122266689853?_trksid=p2060353.m2749.l2649&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT

• Raspberry Pi 3 - 37$

I had the following Items

• 2 3mm LEDs Red/green - Green goes in the back next to the micro USB. This one solders onto the 3.7 volt power supply to show when the batteries charged. The Red LED goes on top of the speaker. This attaches to a DIY battery low circuit (see below). This illuminates the inside of the speaker case.

• Transistors & Resistors - The low battery circuit can be found below. You will need a variable power supply to dial in the pot to get it to the lowest voltage you want (mines 3.6).
http://www.homemade-circuits.com/2013/05/low-battery-indicator-circuit-using-two.html

• 18650 Battery - If you have another battery use it.

Various screws, wire, filament, and time.

This was very fun to build. I think I have everything on here that I used in the build. If I'm missing anything let me know

title: CR-10 40mm Stock Hot End Cooling Duct

description.text:
A much lighter weight, more efficient, and quieter fan duct for the Creality CR-10. It is designed to fit the stock Mk8 style red heatsink hot end. It works with the stock cooling fan. It keeps air flow from blowing on the heater block or going anywhere it shouldn't.

Printed as I did it weighs 7g where the stock metal shroud weighs a porky 44g.

The stock bolts that hold the heatsink to the X carriage are not quite long enough. I used M3x20mm button head screws I had on hand. The stock screws that hold the cooling fan in place will thread nicely into the holes of the printed shroud as they are sized for M3 screws.

I printed with no layer fan as I'm working on a redesign for that also and it came out fine with a few small blobs on the inner support structure and overhangs at the top of the fan opening.

PSA: It has come to my attention that a few people, including myself, experienced the screws going through the shroud loosening over the time of hours worth of printing. Which allows the entire hot end to shift slightly. Make sure you tighten the screws good and tight! And it's not a terrible idea to use a very small amount of BLUE / low strength thread lock on them.

So because I've seen a fair amount of commentary going around that this shouldn't be printed out of PLA...that's incorrect. PLA is just fine. If your heatsink is getting hot enough to hit the glass transition temperature of PLA then there is seriously something wrong. If the heatsink is getting that hot, you will be experiencing lots of jams because the filament will get swollen and melted inside the tube above the heatbreak. With that said, feel free to print out of whatever you want. Keep in mind that most PLA experiences around 2-3% shrink rate so it will fit nice and tight, which is good. Printing it out of PETT or PETG should shrink roughly 1% so it may be a bit more loose.

EDIT: Adding some fan info because there's a LOT of discussion about which fans to replace the super loud stock fan. Here's the thing folks, there has to be both enough CFM (airflow) AND enough static pressure generated to actually be capable of forcing the air through all those fins of the heat sink! Reducing the air flow pathway of a tiny 40x10mm fan hurts them very badly! This is why manufacturers don't care about noise level, they care about a cheap fan that pushes hard enough and fast enough to cool. I highly suggest people stop trying to use Noctua fans for this application. They simply don't push enough CFM or pressure for it. They are quiet, but will quickly lead to clogs and other problems. The BEST option of a Noctua would be a 20mm thick variety as it would produce the most static pressure, but that's not the best option overall.

Here are my recommendations (`30dB noise for these while the stock fan runs close to 70dB. Noctua are mostly 17- 28dB FYI):

For 10mm thick fan
https://www.digikey.com/short/qqmqmf

For a 20mm thick fan
https://www.digikey.com/short/qqmqp7

For a 15mm thick fan
https://www.digikey.com/short/qqmqjr

Super quiet Sunon 10mm, but only 7 CFM and pressure is pretty low at ~30Pa, but still better than a Noctua.
https://www.digikey.com/short/qqmqr7

comments.text: I use 3M high temperature aluminum tape strip on the bottom of these models to reflect all the heat away. Its generally used on wood stoves and can handle around 800(f). Its semi thick but can be cut with scissors and has adhesive on one side too. Its also good to keep any cold air that escapes from the bottom of the fan where there might be a small air gap from escaping.

comments.text: Guys, I just got my CR-10 and am working on the "essential" mods and this is one of the recommended.  I see comment/question about the stock cooling fan on the right side remixing to accommodate it.  The question I have is:  What do I do with the fan on the side if I'm using this duct?
comments.author: u2pilotjt

comments.text: Pick one of the "Fang" style ducts, use the modular dual fan design (I forget who made it), or do what I did for a long time...just stick the stock cooling fan to the side of this duct with a bit of BluTack! :)  I actually used it like that for at least 100 hours and it was generally fine. Plus the BluTack allowed adjustments to the height of the fan and the angle of the air flow for better cooling without getting too much on the nozzle.
comments.author: u2pilotjt

comments.author: MontagueFlange

comments.text: Not particularly necessary if your material shrinks beyond 2%, which most PLA does, it will be a very tight fit around the heatsink. I had to slide mine on from the top and it took a fair amount of effort. It has more than enough grip to hold a 40mm fan in place during the fastest print speeds. The add on 50mm fang duct that others have modeled was never intended to be supported by my design! Although I think if the support struts stay intact it would be just fine. Without them...I'm not sure.
comments.author: MontagueFlange

comments.text: This is really an amazing design.  How did you know the tolerance needed to snap into the heat sink?
comments.author: hu2ng

comments.text: Direct measurements from the heatsink and modeled trying to account for a near 3% shrink rate for PLA. Most PLA shrinks somewhere between 2 and 3.5% during cooling. So really it was a bit of a guess and hoping for the best. In the end I think it came out OK for the filament I used as it was a rather tight snap fit which works well. So well I'm not sure the struts and screw holes are even necessary to keep the fan in place. But that's also assuming not throwing a huge load of a 50mm blower and fang ducts stacked on the front...I never intended that to happen.
comments.author: hu2ng

comments.text: Love the simplicity of the design, Do ya think a couple little tabs at the bottom that extends back to the mounting wall would  help with printhead stabilization?  It looks vulnerable to y axis movements with just the two little screws holding everything in place especially with the fang, 5015 fan and a bowden tube pulling on it
comments.author: Timah81

comments.text: Heh yea, when I designed it there was no intention to piggy back a large duct with a blower on it. So far I haven't had any issues as long as the mount screws are kept tight. And maybe a bit of thread lock used if it works loose at all. I haven't heard anyone else having issues yet, but I can see it could easily become a problem. I may revisit the design and add some extra support.

I'm also using the Fang, I just trimmed a bit off the bottom of the duct outlets and I'm sure it will be no worse than any other layer duct catching on things.

remixed_from.author: Starwhooper
remixed_from.title: improved linear chain to Extruder on Anet A8

description.text:
These prints allowed me to mount the fan on the side and out of the way. Now I can see what I'm printing! And it created a mounting point for one of those cheap endoscopes so I can record what I'm doing.
My extruder fan setup is a little different because I accidently stuck a screw driver into the blades of the old one and it blew up. So I found another one laying around, and I modified it. I have included a fan without a mount and one with a mount that should work with a stock setup. I is designed to mount in between the fan and heat sink. Either way, be sure to support it with wire or the drawn mount, or it will sag from the exturder heat.
Also, it is a good idea to wrap your hot end with some "Ceramic Fiber Insulation Blanket Paper Sheet" from ebay. I found a sheet for under $2. It was left over from insulating the heated bed(I backed it with a piece of sheet metal).
Use "5mm 100ft BGA High Temperature Heat Resistant Polyimide Kapton Tape" from ebay to hold it in place for under $1. Or maybe wire.
The LED lights are the cheap "Bright Warm Cool White DC 12V" I found on ebay for under $6. You can cut it down into groups of 3 and power it with the printers 12v power supply. It's a killer mod to do. You can see even better.
Hope I have uploaded everything you might need. I'm also including my master drawing. Neither of the fans are my work, but everything else is.
Edit: I upgraded the chain mount/limit switch to be higher, so it matched the extruder end. I had to raise the extruder side to clear the fan. So it might not look balanced if you are using a different chain mount. It can be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2158136

title: PNG to StereoProjection
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Someone asked me "Is there an easy way to change the image being projected?"

Yes, we can use the surface() operation to load an image, and then perform the projection() operation to get a 2D object. After that, my stereographic_projection() module can make a stereographic projection from the 2D object. The solution works but the projection() operation is slow.

  • OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

All my png enabled designs.

Find my things about stereographic projection in stereographic_projection.

My library dotSCAD has a stereographic_extrude module. You can use it to create a thing of stereographic projection easily.

  • stereographic_extrude

title: International Women's Day STEM Light Bulb

description.text:
I created this in collaboration with Simplify3D in honor of International Women's Day which is March 8, 2017. The idea I had was to create something that encompassed women in the STEM fields so I came up with a light bulb that has STEM symbols all over it, along with the IWD theme this year which is Be Bold for Change.

I wanted the design to be something that both men and women alike would appreciate and want to print. In addition to that I created 2 models, one is solid while the other is hollow for a 3mm LED to be place inside if you want. I have not had time to do this but hope to do it in the near future.

comments.text: its a shame we celebrate women's day. Instead of segregating engineers into categories of race and sex, we should instead see them as engineers whom so happen to be of a race or sex. A day for women is as pointless as a day for men. We all think and feel. We all are individuals.
comments.author: Jmapscience

comments.text: International Women's Day isn't just about STEM or women in STEM, this was just where I decided to go with my design.  It is about bringing women together, learning different cultures and experiences, expanding our own horizons and helping build up and encourage others who may need it.  This was more my way of celebrating those women who are in the STEM fields on a day meant to empower women of all kinds.

There was a need to replace a simple water line coming thru a wall, and so it was decided to add a nice box at the same time. One screw in the upper right corner is all that is holding this into place.
Used #6 x 1 1/4 (I think) drywall screws to attach the clamp for the valve.
All the parts used were bought from Home Depot and the part numbers are listed on the packaging, so anyone else can do the same right away.
You will want to go in and edit it a bit for the wall plate to fit your preferences.

Note: use a bit extra Teflon tape when attaching the 3/8 compression adaptor to the valve to prevent leaks.

I used PetG because PLA does not like to be in a water environment.

OpenScad file included so you can learn just like I did.
